question: What's the fight?
answer: The Dead Rabbits against the Native Americans, same as ever. But it'll all be settled today.

question: Are you Native or Rabbit?
answer: What do you think?

question: I don't know you.
answer: I suppose there's to be a fight.

question: Derry?
answer: Donnegal. Name's Monk Eastman.

question: And you want to fight, Mr. Eastman?
answer: lf there's money in it.

question: Fight for the Natives. They have a proper war chest.
answer: Well, I might at that. But I thought I'd ask you first, seeing as how I'm not quite a Native American myself.

question: Let's see your skills, and we'll talk of payment later.
answer: Fine. But if you like what you see, pay me double. Monk turns to the door with the grace of a dancer and delivers a SHATTERING kick, sending it flying off its hinges. Clear white LIGHT streams in, and we see Monk Eastman plain for the first time

question: Stand with us then. Bill Poole! on whose challenge are we assembled? A MAN in a leather duster steps forward. He is young, lean and fierce. And then there are his eyes. They do not match. One is real. The other is a huge, bulging PEARL upon which has been engraved, instead of a pupil, a full-color portrait of the AMERICAN EAGLE.
answer: On the challenge of the Native Americans, to settle for good and all who holds sway.

question: Bene.
answer: By the ancient laws of combat, we offer our bodies to the ghosts of those warriors who have gone before us. Valor is avid for glory, and glory is in our wounds.

question: But this time can you bear to look on the glory when it comes, Bill? Can you see it clear with your single eye?
answer: Whoever fights untouched in battle has skill, but the warrior who returns wounded has been touched by God.

question: It wasn't God who touched your eye.
answer: It was God gave me guidance. Will you be able to look on the death blow like a gladiator, and not look away? No honorable man turns an eye from his death.

question: I don't expect a death blow from your hand, Butcher. Let's have at it.
answer: There is another matter.

question: Say it out and quick, before spring gets here.
answer: No Native American Warrior will dishonor himself with the blood of the halt and maimed.

question: So?
answer: So we would like to know whether Squire Jack Mulraney of the Dead Rabbits can smile out of both sides of his face.

question: Where's your family, sonny?
answer: My mother's just there. On the trip, her insides all broke up. She wasn't dead and there was three others fighting for her bed.

question: And your father? Where's he, then?
answer: I never knew him.

question: Where all those streets come together right ahead is the true Five Points. But most speak of the Five Points and mean anywhere between the Battery and the Bowery. Although the night's cold, the streets are jammed. WHORES painted like carnival Gypsies sell themselves to any man sober enough to stand up. SOUNDS of laughter and combat filter out from garish SALOONS like the Little Naples, the Hell Hole, the Egyptian Hall. In the midst of all this highlife are BEGGARS and the SICKLY, looking for charity, scrounging garbage in the street. An INDIGENT battles a CRIPPLE for a meager scrap of faod. A richly dressed WOMAN, riding by in a carriage, hides her eyes by raising a HUGE BOUQUET OF FLOWERS in front of her face. Streets hereabouts are lively of an evening. The city comes here to sport. But there's places to put up a boy on his own.
answer: And those? What are those?

question: We passed the plate amongst ourselves. Come up with enough ned to carry all this, and carry you a while, too.
answer: Where will my father rest?

question: Potters Field, with everyone else.
answer: My father won't be buried with everyone else. He'll lie separate in fresh ground, facing east.

question: What difference where he faces?
answer: He'll face east for the second coming of Christ.

question: Tomorrow your cortege will cross Paradise Square, into territory protected by the Native Americans. You will be permitted undisputed passage both ways. That is our tribute. After that, any Rabbits wishing to join the Native Americans and willing to swear blood loyalty will be welcomed. All others will be dispatched. He starts out of the silent room, but STOPS when he sees Mank Eastman looking at him with easy interest. Bill the Butcher STARES him down, but Monk's gaze never wavers. I'll expect you first.
answer: Me? Oh, I don't know. All that talk of blood loyalty makes me quake. I'll spill blood when the price is right. But blood for ceremony? I prefer holy communion.

question: You saw us fight today. You know we can pay any price.
answer: Not mine. Not now, and not any time after.

question: What do they call you?
answer: Amsterdam.

question: Your full name.
answer: Vallon.

question: First name?
answer: I told you.

question: Address?
answer: Got none.

question: I'll put city. Now what's your age? Maybe twelve. Got a family?
answer: No more.

question: Well, where was they from when you had one?
answer: City.

question: You come into the Five Points and you stole from me.
answer: I don't know...

question: You stole Vallon. He was my kill. My example, of my power. You took him and made him yours.
answer: You're a lunatic to come here like...

question: Thank you. Just listen good. The Native Americans holds the Five Points. We have prevailed. What you do outside the Points is your deciding. Outside is your city. Inside the Points is mine. Anyone who says different, or does different, or thinks different... ... theylll draw my unwelcame attention. You understand?
answer: I do understand, yes. But you don't understand at all. There's a whole city to share and all you see is your own narrow streets.

question: You just stay out of my place.
answer: Yes, alright. Gladly. It's all blackjack jobs and panel games and killings for a fiver.

question: It's good work.
answer: As far as it goes.

question: You wouldn't be talking to me otherwise.
answer: But we're talking about different things, Bill. You describe the present. I see the possibilities. Look to the future. There is so much more. There's things demanding to be done that no police force can do, not even an obedient one. There's contributions from every dive and brothel. Loyalties to be secured and debts to be collected.

question: We work for no one.
answer: ... beside Tammany... in the performance of these civic obligations. And for a satisfactory... I'm prepared even to say equitable... financial participation. It's not the sort of responsibility the founding fathers might have recognized. But then, the founding fathers never imagined the city New York has become.

question: Maybe you Tammany boys should do your own lifting and carrying and muscle work. Might build you up.
answer: We'd like to. I do miss it. But it's wiser for men in the public life to give an appearance of probity.

question: Then get cops to do it.
answer: Oh Jesus, no. The appearance of law must be upheld, especially while it's being broken.

question: Appearance means nothing.
answer: Perhaps not within the Points. But the smart man could go higher.

question: Head straight out, then turn for the current.
answer: Figured you for dead.

question: Close enough.
answer: This is my crew. And welcome to join, if you've the mettle. We're river pirates and quick thieves and street brawlers...

question: You're lost.
answer: Yeah? You've no business saying anything against us! Do you know how much you cost us? You know how much that body's worth?

question: I doubt it's worth the water it's floating in.
answer: Fifteen dollars! Fifteen dollars from them medical ghouis.

question: I'll make it back for you whatever it is, once we're in the city. Just keep sailing, or we're all done for.
answer: Go ahead then. He was in his prime. He'd have fetched thirty dollars easy.

question: Does Shang have the sand to ever go against the Natives?
answer: I don't know. He acts like it.

question: If he only acts, held be better on the stage. Like her.
answer: Jenny Everdeane. Shang turned her into the best bludget in the Points.

question: Shes his mort, is she, as well as his best provider?
answer: Yeah. But Jenny says she's anyone's she chooses.

question: That's the prize of the month. Spice Islands silk. You'll learn our way if you're going to be one of us, Amsterdam. Every one of us gives a portion of all they steal to the gang. Morts more than men, being morts.
answer: Yeah? And why is that?

question: Because morts have more resources. Men can work only on their feet, but a mort can turn out on her back.
answer: I mean, why give at all? Why don't they keep for themselves?

question: If you think there's something off about my way of running things, you got no place in this gang.
answer: I got no place anyway, and you got no gang. This ain't a gang, no matter what you say. It's a mob.

question: Is that sand we've just seen?
answer: It's politics.

question: I've got my own way to go, why don't you find yours?
answer: Because your way's different, and I want to see where it goes. Unless you say otherwise. Amsterdam shrugs and keep walking. You act like you have something in mind, like you know every day what you'll be doing the next. Me, I don't figure on tomorrow.

question: Well, if you shut up a while maybe it'd come on its own. Now what the hell's that?
answer: Oh that's heaven. The city shut down the Brewery as unfit to live and Tammany gave it over to this minister. Why Tammany ... you don't know? Tammany makes the city run. A political organization that's like... like the Native Americans, only ranging over the whole city. They seem like the law, but they got a way of acting outside the law. Anything that happens in this city, on the straight or on the sly, Tammany's a part of, and Boss Tweedls the heart of Tammany.

question: But the season is vicious, and I must take thought of our constituents. Mr. Gleason, I'd like you to shake hands with Mr. Barnett Baff... A friend and owner of an estimable carting service. Work out an arrangement whereby the citizenry can receive the benefit of Mr. Gleason's wondrous elixir outside this excellent box. At a cost, Mr. Gleason, of how much the barrel ... ...and how much, Mr. Baff, for haulage and distribution... At least. That's a price of fifty dollars. And greedy, low piracy at that But a price that Tammany, in its generosity, will meet. Merely submit a bill for a hundred. We'll each have half. And I'll retain this box for further experiment. Hello, Bill. Bolt the door. Scotchy Lavelle's gone wrong in his accounts.
answer: I know. Scotchy's a good man.

question: Not good enough to rake thirty percent of our share from Sparrow's and use it for his own. You got to give him over, Bill.
answer: I can't do that. No matter what he steals, I still get more from him than any two others. As do you.

question: Alright then. What about Charles McGloin? He's running a panel game off to one side. Did you know that? I can't get a day's work done for all the good citizens pouring in here complaining about crime and corruption all over the Points. They accuse Tammany of carelesoness. Some even suspect ... a few practically suggest. ... our complicity with this rampant criminality. We must show them Tammany stands behind the letter of the law. We need to set an example.
answer: Charles McGloin will do.

question: I hope you won't think me rude if I speak.
answer: No, sir. You look a proper Gentleman down to the ground.

question: Well, I wouldn't want you to think me forward, you see.
answer: Does it matter to you what I think?

question: Well, I might like it to.
answer: Oh.

question: I mean, if you would like.
answer: I might like, sir. But I can't say now.

question: Why?
answer: Because this is my stop.

question: May I walk with you a little, then?
answer: That would be too bold.

question: But I'll never see you again.
answer: I come every Thursday to the Tombs to see my father.

question: May I walk with you a little, then?
answer: Are you a spy, then?

question: Got no one to spy for. I'm an appreciator, you might say.
answer: Appreciator of what?

question: A good touch.
answer: Don't bother with the chat. If you want me, we come to a business arrangement. lf the terms is right, then I decide how you suit me. Then I do it or not.

question: Just take a minute, I was Just...
answer: I know what you was just. I had years already of what you was just. You know how I got so good at thieving? So's I wouldn't have to lay down for everyone who had the ned. Now I do it when I want to for how much I want to. Otherwise I don't do it, and don't have to do it, and to hell with anyone's rules but my own.

question: What about Shang's rules? You pay a lot over to him. The better your day, the better his. It don't seem gute right.
answer: What's it to you?

question: Give him this. And you can keep a little more of what you earned.
answer: How'd you come by this?

question: I got my own touch.
answer: Are you making me a present, or making an Arrangement?

question: You know that's Jack's.
answer: It should be hangin' off Jack's vest, then. Not here, like some war flag.

question: That watch is a small price for free run of the Points.
answer: If it's free, how come we pay so much? Wo shouldn't pay for what's our due.

question: We don't tight when we don't have to. It's not warring that counts. It's the living day to day.
answer: So then.

question: I gave no order for this.
answer: Never mind giving orders. What were you giving this for?

question: I'm calling you out, Amsterdam.
answer: I got this at the hanging. It was Charles McGloin's. Everybody here saw you take it from Jenny. What was MCGloin doing with it? What'd you give it to him for?

question: I didn't give it to him. Why would I give it to him?
answer: I gaw you give it to him. Last week, behind the Old Brewery.

question: He's gone flat. I got no reason to trade with the Native Americans.
answer: What about stepping up in the world, as it were, and leaving the rest of us behind. There's a reason. Making a separate arrangement for yourself with the one Native so stupid and luckless that he got hung. That's you to the ground, Shang.

question: Who believes what he's saying? Can any of you believe what he's saying?
answer: Bene. We'll see. Any of you that believes I did proper by Happy Jack Mulraney tonight, stand beside me. Any of you that still likes Shang's way with the cops, and Shang's way with the Natives, go to him. Or should we settle right now, you and me, and just see which of us is left standing?

question: Let see where they stand.
answer: What's your pleasure, Shang? This mob ever have a proper name?

question: You were waiting for me out here, weren't you?
answer: Maybe I was, yeah.

question: You was that sure of me?
answer: Sure enough to wait, anyway. Waiting don't cost nothing.

question: It don't do to be sure. I could go away just as easy.
answer: Alright.

question: I'll say when I want to, not you.
answer: Stay then. One way or another, I get what I want.

question: Yeah. If it was just a shag you wanted.
answer: You're a gypsy, are you, come to tell my fortune? Go ahead then. Tell me what I'm wanting.

question: You got blood in your eye for someone.
answer: It's just I can't look away, that's all.

question: Who from?
answer: Bill Poole.

question: You better get someone else in your sights. No one's ever taken him.
answer: 'Cause he's mine, that's why. I'll take his one eye, and then the rest of him, piece by small piece.

question: You have a plan for this? You going to raise a militia? I'll wager Bill the Butcher don't even know about you or care if he does.
answer: He'll know about me soon enough.

question: And after the Butcher?
answer: You.

question: Is that so?
answer: You'll be in love with me.

question: Love you? You just had me. You can have a mort any time you want. So why look for more than that.
answer: That's taking love, not giving it. I want it to be just you and me, no one else for either.

question: Why?
answer: 'Cause none of us means nothing in life except one to the other.

question: I don't know I want to mean something, to you or anybody. Can there be good in that?
answer: We'll see.

question: It'll take a while if we do. If we ever do.
answer: And what about the meantime?

question: ... remarkable...
answer: Our own Tammany man. We are coming along. Happy to meet any friend of Johnny Siroccols.

question: Likewise. Pleasure to meet the best but one in the whole Five Points.
answer: Best but one? Who's better?

question: Maybe nobody. But when the count's done the numbers will tell who's come out in front.
answer: I'm in no race. Just pay us what you owe.

question: It's all right, Nat. They're saying the truth. They gave a good day's work for a good wage. A fine first showing. But second best.
answer: Second, eh? You don't say so.

question: It's no shame to be bested by veterans. The Native Americans always sweep the field.
answer: What?

question: We count on them sure as mass comes an Sunday.
answer: Did you know this? Is this some scheme of yours?

question: I was working the same side as the Natives? The Natives?
answer: That's only right. Bill the Butcher's our ambassador throughout the Points, as you might say. It's deemed an honor to work with him. Everyone knows Bill Poole, everyone fears him, everyone ...

question: I sure as hell don't fear him. And I sure as hell won't stand with him, or any who calls him one of theirs.
answer: Well, if it's matter of personal honor, the money can only be a further insult. I have no wish to rile you further, so if you'll allow me...

question: Where is he? Where's Bill the Butcher?
answer: Listen, buck. This is a Tammany night. If you and Bill Poole have matters to settle, you can do it any other time, any other place, I don't give a good dancing goddamn. But you do it here tonight and all the Five Points will be down on you like the righteous wrath of heaven. or you could, as the Book says, put away childish things. Join the celebration. Personally, I always find the least strenuous solution the most appealing. Don't you?

question: I got experience. It's the education I lack.
answer: And you heard I was a good teacher?

question: I don't listen to talk, I figure for myself. And I figured you'd be good at everything you did.
answer: That's right.

question: And tonight I got the ned.
answer: And now what?

question: Now I'm ready for you. Unless there's an arrangement between you and Amsterdam.
answer: Not to my thinking.

question: Amsterdam... listen up, Amsterdam...
answer: You going with me or him? It's my thinking matters here. You don't have to ask him nothing.

question: What?
answer: How's the evening passing?

question: Fine. Why?
answer: 'Cause it's treating me fine too.

question: Evening, sir. Are you prepared to be celebrated? Are you ready to be famous? Just a moment of your time. My men will assist you. What's it so quiet for? I don't need quiet. There's for your beauty and your song.
answer: Mr. Poole! Bill Poole! My compliments on your exhibition, sir.

question: Thank you, sir.
answer: It was like watching a dance. Some great grand goddamned dance. You know me, sir.

question: Do I? Are you missing a finger?
answer: No. A father.

question: Do you have a name?
answer: Amsterdam.

question: That's a New York name. shall we drink to it?
answer: Indeed. And to my other name. Vallon. Will you drink to that?

question: Priest Vallon's son? Of course I'll drink to that. Your father was a worthy man.
answer: Not worthy of you. Those dogs ain't worthy of you. You ain't worth what they feed on, and what they shit's too good for you.

question: What do you want, boyo?
answer: I got to give you something, Butcher. Something from my father.

question: What do you say? Loin or shank? Rib or chop? Come on, let me hear you! You're all talking at once, I can't hear you! I don't hear the choicest cut! The best, the vital! The heart. I think I must have the heart! Come on, look at it! You fancy yourself a gladiator, act a gladiator! Watch the death blow when it comes to you. Go to hell with open eyes!
answer: It's been a full evening's fun now, Butcher. It's enough.

question: You got nothing to do with this, Monk. The hell.
answer: It was his father took me in first, and it's thanks I'm returning now.

question: Eastman!
answer: This squares any debt. Get him out of here.

question: Monk Eastman! I'll have you then!
answer: Come ahead, Bill. Unless you're wanting to shout me to death.

question: That so? What's he look like? Indeed.- Can I buy you a shave?
answer: No thanks.

question: Face is too sore, eh? I understand.
answer: No. I'm beholden enough to you as it is. I don't like to be beholden.

question: We're all even, son. There's nothing more between us.
answer: I'd like it if there was.

question: Are you proposing employment?
answer: A collaboration. The Dead Rabbits got to get strong before we make another move. I figure you're the one to make us strong. There's a lot we can learn from you.

question: Boyo, I'm a freebooter and a mercenary, not a teacher. I can't learn nothing from you and I can't earn nothing from you either.
answer: The Dead Rabbits is going to be glorious again. We're going to reign over the Points.

question: And Bill Poole's Natives? What will they have to say?
answer: Nothing. They won't have tongues left to speak.

question: Don't worry about what theylll have in their mouths. You think about what they got in their hands. Listen, son... take a word from a man who was honored to fight beside your father. Temper yourself like a sword, and pay attention to balance. Anger spoils an edge.
answer: Then you say no?

question: You see my instrument there? First notch represents two dollars and fifty cents. That's how much I got for my first kill. There are forty-eight more notches after it, and my fee has grown with each one. I can accommodate you alright, but you got to afford me. So do business with me or do it on your own.
answer: Everything I got is still to come. So I guess it's on my own, then.

question: Fair enough. You'll find independence a fine thing, a fierce thing. Although I do hold money preferable to all.
answer: Bound to.

question: Tammany's here to take the chill off the winter and the weight off your heart. It's Tammany can make this city a fit place, with the help and vote of all you good people...
answer: You sent me word.

question: We could use help here. Grab a sack.
answer: I keep my hands clean.

question: So I've observed.
answer: Better be on your mark to talk like that to me. It was you stopped me at the Pagoda. I would have cut Monk inside out.

question: What if you hadn't? Think of the embarrassment. And what if you had? Consider the waste. Next time you're in a dust-up like that, think ahead and make proper plans. It'd be a grand source of revenue, whoever prevails.
answer: It touches my heart how you always. have our best interests in mind.

question: Our mutual interests. That's why I want you to contact Monk Eastman. I want you to extend a proposition. I want him to join US.
answer: What?

question: Oh, not Tammany, of course not. We could no more have him there than you. But he should throw in with the Native Americans, become aware of our Arrangement and ... well, use his influence, shall we say, to enrich us all.
answer: You're saying I can't do everything you need? You don't think the Natives has been doing good and right? You think there's something more he can do that I ...

question: It's none of that, Bill. None of that. His independence is like a rebuke to Tammany. And an insult to you.
answer: Then you should have let me have him at Sparrow's.

question: I should. If I'd been confident-absolutely certain--that you would have prevailed. Monk is an unpredictable power, and a figure of size. He needs to be reckoned with.
answer: He needs to be killed.

question: And this is your offer?
answer: It's Boss Tweedls offer.

question: How do you think we'd sit as allies, Bill?
answer: The only way we could tolerate being near each other would be stretched out dead.

question: My thoughts exactly. Then why are you here? Because you were asked to be. You were ordered to be. And who would order me among the Natives? You? And would you follow my orders, even if they was being relayed from William Marcy Tweed himself? Dubious and doubtful, my friend. But your offer--pardon, the offer you bring--is the most generous that's ever been extended. I favor the terms, if not the personalities. So let us decide the way any Native American would appreciate. We'll do it the democratic way. Citizens of the Five Points! It seems the Native Americans have come to trouble. They have grown so weak that now they seek my help. They can pay any wage I ask. But I ask you now. Even for money, should I carouse and conspire alongside a boyo like this with gristle on his knife and spittle on his chin every time his cock gets hard? There. You see. I'm afraid the people have spoken.
answer: I'll see you again, you bog Irish bastard.

question: You're still welcome, even with such peculiar appetites.
answer: But if the Natives do come, Father...

question: I'm not a priest, son ...
answer: ... there's no accounting for what may follow.

question: So you accept?
answer: What?

question: You accept to be my mort and no one else's.
answer: No, it's just that I didn't recognize you in the mirror. You still got some of the face the Butcher gave you.

question: It's not the Butcher, it's the dancing. It shifts my face all around.
answer: Maybe you'll look better later.

question: I will if we're together later. And what about after that? After tonight?
answer: I chose you just for tonight. If that's not good enough I'll go with someone else.

question: I'll have tonight. But after this don't come to me no more till you're ready. No more.
answer: Amsterdam. Amsterdam!

question: Who is it?
answer: Me.

question: Come on in.
answer: I don't want to come in! You come out.

question: I'm going to fight you.
answer: Oh, Jesus, Johnny, I'm tired. How about sometime else?

question: Now.
answer: You want to tell me what this fight's over? Is it The Butcher? Jenny? Alright, alright. Then tell me why like this?

question: So when I lose no one will see.
answer: Satisfied?

question: Satisfied? It wasn't me that's been dancing and shagging all night.
answer: Enough. That's it then.

question: The hell.
answer: Goddamn it. Goddamn you anyway.

question: What's the trouble, Don? It's just a man of commerce.
answer: You're right enough this time, Monk. Go ahead. Go on with your work. I'll finish my business.

question: Come out with it then.
answer: You damn craven, do it!

question: What the hell...
answer: Your eyes was open for that alright. And you still got one to see this. If I was you I'd use that to open in a new location. Consider St. Louis. The war club. I promise you, Amsterdam. I promise you.

question: I'm not good enough for your table, so I eat where I can. It's good, what is it?
answer: Pheasant.

question: Is that like pigeon? I killed a pigeon once but it didn't taste nothing like this.
answer: You killed a bull this morning. I told you to make an Arrangement with him, and you come back with his blood on your hands.

question: He insulted me. He aggravated me. I couldn't stand for that, for no one.
answer: You stand for anything if I tell you.

question: You think I should be afraid of you. You act like lightning strikes when you talk. I never was afraid of you, so don't think I was or act like I was, you ain't earned it.
answer: What did you earn us, killing Monk?

question: Where'd you earn the right to ask that question? You raised some dust in the streets a while back, but no more. You got power but you ain't got muscle and you ain't got a notion what it means to be a warrior.
answer: I see it lost you a lot of God's sense, along with that eye.

question: You don't know nothing about that! It was my doing! It says in The Book, "If thy eye offend thee, pluck it out." I followed that law with my own knife and hand. The first I ever fought Priest Vallon, he bested me. And when he came to bring me to death, I looked away and he watched me and he let me go. The shame was worse than the killing. I would have cut out both eyes if I could still have fought, but cutting just the one gave me heart. When I killed Priest Vallon, that restored me. Now I sent Monk Eastman over I got glory. I got all there is, and small thanks to you, squire.
answer: You need two eyes to see the depth, Bill. That's how we help each other. If it wasn't for me would be happy enough to plunder the Points and put the fear into people who don't know nothing else. But Bill, I'm only saying... I'm counselinm... look in the distance. You want to sit at my table, fine. But you must always remember who the host is. It's not a matter of courage welre talking. It's manners.

question: Howls these manners?
answer: Fine, if you're hungry.

question: I'm always hungry.
answer: I've always told you, Bill. There's plenty for all, and more for us together than separate. We'll dine together sometime.

question: Let me put this to you, Daniel. Now that the Butcher has killed the single most prominent figure in the Five Points--a man of myth and moment--who is there to take his place? Of course. Then what do we do about the Butcher? He's too useful to be killed, but he must be checked. Impossible! Any cops who might have the mettle to go against the Butcher have blood ties to the gangs. They can't be trusted. And any cops that can be trusted are too craven to be any use. If Bill's to be checked, it must come from within the Points, not without.
answer: The Dead Rabbits did a proud job for elections. That Amsterdam boy has sand.

question: That so? The last time I saw him he was under the Butcher's knife looking like a fine filet. Who else is there?
answer: Well, the Rough and Tumble Boys over to Slaughterhouse Point. There's Country McCleesterls bunch, too, and the Plug Uglies, but there's none that have the promise of the Dead Rabbits, or the stake, neither.

question: What would that be?
answer: The boy Amsterdam has a blood feud with the Butcher. He's sworn revenge for the death of his father, and he's got the heart to carry it forward. He'll have the skill and power soon enough.

question: Blood will make a man intrepid. Bring them along, then. Nurture the Rabbits with neglect. Let them roam where they like.
answer: And if they roam into some portion of our own revenues?

question: I'd tolerate a little trespassing if it was for a higher good and use. They'll cross with the Natives soon enough and keep each other occupied.
answer: Bill's got to be a lot more than occupied.

question: I'll hold Bill in check. If he becomes unwieldy ... well, damn it all, Daniel, I might just have to oil up my old musket. What do you think of that, eh?
answer: It'd be gratifying, Mr. Tweed. Even edifying.

question: I got ned enough for all. See? Fair enough? What's our rate? What do we charge?
answer: Johnny worked it out to a nickel less than the Natives. Just till we're established. Then we raise it a penny more than now.

question: Raise it? Is that what you want?
answer: You say, then.

question: There'll be no paying at all this day. Or this week, neither. This is Dead Rabbits business from now on. We'll take ned if you got it, now or in future. But no one will go without.
answer: Except us. You opening a charity?

question: They'll pay us what they owe, in loyalty if not in cash. Tammany gives coal, we give milk.
answer: They can afford it.

question: You liked that old man? You would have gone with him?
answer: I like anyone that pays, that's all.

question: Tell me what he wanted you to do.
answer: He mostly wanted comforting.

question: I never seen hair so black. Can you take the pins out?
answer: It takes so long to do back up.

question: Did your mother have the same color? Lie back, I want to look at you. What's that mark?
answer: I always had it.

question: And there? Is that a scar?
answer: There was a baby. They cut it out.

question: And that on your shoulder? That looks old.
answer: Yeah, I got that when I ...

question: I don't want to know when. Don't tell me about before or what you used to be, I don't want that.
answer: What about your scars. Do you have scars?

question: Go on. I can see you later. Megs leaves, brushing past Jenny.
answer: What are you doing?

question: I couldn't decline what Mother Joyce offered. It's in the interests of business. You understand business.
answer: Sure I do. But there's something else I still don't understand. At Sparrow's Pagoda, did you hit me, knowing it was me?

question: Yeah. I did.
answer: Meantime's over.

question: Oh fine. That's fine. I'd be celebrating but I'm losing too much blood.
answer: Put your head back.

question: That don't work.
answer: Put your head back I said.

question: So why so sudden, then?
answer: Sudden? Every day I see you and you complain I can't decide. Now I decide, you say it's sudden.

question: It's the whore did it, then.
answer: Don't flatter yourself.

question: It's because you're jealous.
answer: It's because you didn't lie about hitting me.

question: Christ, I wish I had. Come here, then.
answer: Not here. There's too much past.

question: It must be morning.
answer: I don't care, I'm not getting up.

question: This is what you meant, then? It's going to be just the same from now on?
answer: What?

question: Every morning I wake up next to you.
answer: Or you don't wake up at all.

question: We only just started in and you're already threatening me.
answer: It's not a threat. It's a declaration of love.

question: I prefer my kind. This kind.
answer: What's this? Where'd you get this?

question: You said I was the best thief in the Five Points. But I got restless. Will you wear something I got?
answer: What is this place?

question: My jeweler's. Come on.
answer: I don't see nobody.

question: That's the best time. They're all having lunch.
answer: You're off your head.

question: You can wait on me a minute. Or I'll see you back in the Points if you're scared. Don't worry. I know every house on this street. They all leave their doors open. They live like they're not in New York. Come on. I might still be taken for a maid. But you're nobody's notion of a butler. The Police Commissioner lives the next street over. I was thinking of visiting him next month, but cops don't buy goods. They keep all their graft in cash. How's that for ten minutes?
answer: It's a lot to fence.

question: I'm not going to fence it. I'm going to keep it and take it where no one will recognize it.
answer: Where would that be?

question: Somewhere west. Far west. Past the Mississippi River, somewhere into that territory.
answer: That's a hard journey for a woman alone.

question: You'd be with me.
answer: You got it all planned and straight, is that it?

question: Once I said I'd be with you I wanted someplace we could be together. Someplace better than here. What's the matter with that?
answer: Nothing. Except there's no place but here for me right now. I got to settle things.

question: Yeah, I know, but I'm talking about settling down, not settling debts.
answer: You don't have my obligations.

question: Excuse me. We'll conclude in a moment. Where do you settle?
answer: Amsterdam, what are you saying?

question: I'm asking, where does anyone settle?
answer: I don't know, you mean a place, a home?

question: These lead all under the Square, into the Brewery and out again from there. They're closed off and forgotten since the Reverend opened the mission. Pass me the candle. We lived in this building till she lost her seamstress work and we went to the Brewery. One day she slept so drunk she never woke and I brought her back here. Dug this myself. Families. Give here what I gave you. She'll keep an eye on this for us. How about some help?
answer: You trusting me with your treasure, then?

question: Just take another look at it to remind you. I can always do fine on my own. What's mine is yours, is that it?
answer: I could use this, too.

question: You making an offering to the Reverend Raleigh?
answer: Are you sure we can trust your mother?

question: The building and how many?
answer: A dozen at least of my Natives.

question: The Dead Rabbits are a wooly bunch alright.
answer: I want at them. All of them, and Amsterdam especial. Now.

question: Not just now. It's between too late and too soon. They've become a little too prominent for comfort, but they're still too small for you to soil your hands. The man who killed Monk Eastman pushing around a mob of upstarts. It's practically undignified.
answer: To hell with any of that.

question: Very well, and to hell as well with any plans you and I may have for growth and change and even greater reward. You'll never advance anywhere beyond the limited perimeter of your imagination.
answer: I don't got to advance anywhere further.

question: Got to, no. But ought to.
answer: What's this?

question: He never had his own cross. Thanks. Your touch is light, but as a tracker you work awful heavy. Come ahead. Now that I met your mother, you should come and meet my father.
answer: You should finish the stone.

question: It'll be finished when everything's finished. That's when helll rest. The hand that killed him is the hand that will bury him in peace.
answer: It was Bill killed him, not you.

question: With my hand on the knife.
answer: And his hand on yours!

question: And me feeling the life go out of my father! He looked at me ... he looked at me and he swore me with his eyes. I could feel his spirit... I say I could feel it rising... flowing through the knife like blood into my own heart.
answer: You talk like he lives in you.

question: I don't want him to live, I want him dead! I kill Bill and I'm free of them both!
answer: You think you can be free that easy? You need your way so clear, and you''' use anything to clear it. Anyone, too. Me, everybody, we're all just a way for you to settle your damned ghosts.

question: Dobbs will take him this round. That'll be something. The Natives has never lost before.
answer: Because there's never been a Dead Rabbit fighting before.

question: That'll shame them thorough.
answer: There'll be worse than shaming. We only got the Natives in range.

question: Don't push the Natives too far, Amsterdam. Otherwise it'll be Tammany pushing back.
answer: That don't matter any more.

question: It does matter, and it's going to matter even more. Tammany's the heart and future of this city. If the Rabbits is going to keep growing, we're going to have to throw in with Tammany some way. They got that Conscription Act from Washington keeping them busy, but they won't leave us alone forever. And the Natives is strong as they ever been!
answer: You call that strong, John? This is our time now!

question: No thanks owed, son. Conscription's Federal Law, and so's the $300 exemption. You might remind your father, though, that you saw me here today, minding that the law's strictly and equitably enforced.
answer: You see how much they like this damned law? Enforcing it's going to hurt us in elections.

question: It's not my law, and not my liking, either. But Washington's always treated us with sufferance, and we must extend the same regard to them. Boys, we are bound by honor and love of country to fight in this time of crisis! Boys, the union is in distress, our land is wounded deeply, our future is suddenly a frail and finite thing. We must ask ourselves how... Thank you, boys, thank you for your understanding. Holy Mother. Daniel, between the blindness of Washington and the damned brass of Bill Poole Tammany will fall like an autumn leaf. We must take what measures we can. Attend to the Butcher. After the elections, of course. Unless you think Amsterdam will do our work for us first.
answer: He could at that. Then he would become a fresh concern

question: Sheeny Mike, you want to make ... ...how much? Five dollars? Just to help us?
answer: What's the pitch, Johnny? Amsterdam wouldn't like it, working with Tammany.

question: He knows about it. Welre working a whole new scheme. But I won't tell him youlre helping, if that's the way you want it. And you can keep the full five. Just start climbing.
answer: Where's the ned?

question: He was working a Tammany job, Tammany will see to him.
answer: He wasn't Tammany. Not like you.

question: He made the right choice.
answer: You don't know what you're saying! You killed one of our own. One of your family!

question: That must be the vanguard of Barnum's army.
answer: This city will burn like Gomorrah.

question: Then we'll take what we can before it gets too hot.
answer: I think it's past that already.

question: It'll never come to that. These people ain't gang-led and they have no purpose. Fight better and not get so mad. They're only doing what they should have done years ago. Why'd they ever think there was another way to live?
answer: They believed what people told them, that's all.

question: What people is that? The Reverend at the mission? Boss Tweed? Daniel Killoran? People like Johnny Sirocco?
answer: You believed Johnny.

question: Hell.
answer: And I believed you.

question: I ain't done nothing different than what I told you, Jen.
answer: I believed what you said abaut being with me, with me alone. But you lied to me. It's not me alone, it's just you and Bill Poole. Youlre so blood-blind you can't see nothing else, not even this!

question: I don't care a fine damn about what they want! It's what I want! They won't dare harm the Points, that's all I care about! Let them turn the rest of the city into hell! It's another country anyway.
answer: It's not a country for me, Amsterdam. I don't know about you. Will you come with me?

question: Not now.
answer: Now is when I'm going. Will you come?

question: 101 INT. UNDERGROUND/JACOB'S LADDER
answer: What is it?

question: 103 EXT. STREET/FIVE POINTS NIGHT
answer: I'd kill you for this.

question: No we ain't going to fight, but we can take something for ourselves out of this.
answer: I want to know who hung them bodies in the Bloody Angle. I want to address who done it.

question: Five thousand people in the street done it! Boss Tweed done it! Abe Lincoln done it! There's nothing you can do about any one of them but stay with us. You'll have a little of your own back.
answer: How's that?

question: He's here on our business and my invitation. He's already been of great help. What's the opposition strength, John?
answer: Each candle is against you, gents. Some of us come from those people, Mayor. I'll not deny they still claim part of me.

question: Gentlemen, I'm sorry you find it necessary to question the loyalty of my friend here, and by extension, my own judgement. So as proof ... John, where will the mob go? What will the gangs do? Go on, tell them what you told me.
answer: There's no telling about the mob. Or the small gangs. But the Dead Rabbits ... if I was Amsterdam...

question: As indeed you nearly was. Were.
answer: ... if I was ... I'd figure to take the Rabbits to the Armory.

question: Would you agree with that, Bill? Wouldn't you do the same? If you were fighting against the militia instead of beside them?
answer: Beside them? What are you talking... ?

question: You will have to fight beside them to take the Armory. It cannot fall into unfriendly hands.
answer: I can't stand with the militia against the people. I could never work the Points no more if I did.

question: I'm sure that Bill will do his usual splendid job. But after that ... well, I'm afraid he's grown away from us. He shows distressing signs of... shall we say, free-thinking. Crime flourishes in chaos, and these riots could encourage Bill to overstep himself. He no longer inspires in me the same trust... well, that you might. If you can prove yourself further.
answer: You already said in front of everyone you trusted me.

question: In vital things. Would I be talking to you now otherwise? Vital things, but small things. Are you equal to greater responsibility and opportunity?
answer: Such as what?

question: Not a bit.
answer: Are you here to spy?

question: I don't have to spy. I know what you're doing. I told Tweed what you're doing.
answer: You don't know what I'm doing.

question: You're going after the Armory.
answer: Am I now? Why do you think that?

question: 'Cause that's what I would do, and you and I think alike.
answer: No more. And it don't seem worth a visit to tell me something you already think I'm doing.

question: There's something else alright. Tweed's arranged to kill Bill the Butcher.
answer: Who could Tweed get to do that?

question: One of his own.
answer: There's no one around him...

question: Listen, it don't matter who, it's going to be done, that's all! Tweed ain't going to wait around for you and Bill to settle yourselves. I'm telling you so you have a chance.
answer: Chance of what?

question: A chance... a chance to do what you want. Bury the Butcher, draw what blood you got to. But you better make speed. The Natives will move on the Armory too.
answer: And what's any of it mean to you?

question: It means whatever's left of friendship, I don't know. There's still part of me here. I don't want to see you lose everything in your life at once.
answer: I'm going to lose nothing. If you believe me, you can stay.

question: Murder Me? No one's going to murder me.
answer: Then you better learn to fight locking over your shoulder, Bill, because that's the only way you'll ever see it coming.

question: I don't believe it, and I don't believe it's you telling me. You got no reason to care about any danger to me.
answer: One reason. You're my kill, Butcher. No one else is going to have you, not Tweed, not Tammany, not those pigs in the street. No one--not even you, Bill--will ever take the pleasure of your death away from me. I'd do anything to keep you for my own, even if I have to protect you.

question: You protect me? Get out of here and go to hell.
answer: Fine, so long as I pass you on my way.

question: Maybe I'd believe you more if I knew who was talking to you.
answer: Someone I credit.

question: That means nothing to me. None of this means nothing to me because I am Tammany. Without me and my Natives they're nothing but a bunch of old horses at a trough.
answer: You join with me and we fight against Tammany, fight them back and out of the Points. Then you and me can settle. But if you don't join with me, then there won't be no settlement because you'll be murdered in the street and the whole Points will be mine.

question: I relish the thought... just the thought... of cutting you up and opening you wide. So if just thinking about it gives me such pleasure, imagine how I'm going to enjoy doing it.
answer: Why don't I make it easy for you, then. Same as you're making it easy for Tweed.

question: Amsterdam! Don't be like your father. Don't make it too easy.
answer: Where's the Native Americans? And the militia? That's why he sent us.

question: We move now and we can drive them out! We press them and they'll break! Tweed put me in charge of this! I say we move, and by the crucified Christ we will move! Native Americans, come with me! Any militia that wants to live upright instead of die hunkered down, come with us! We'll show you gladiators' greatness! Come on! Was it Tweed or your friend put you to this?
answer: Tweed.

question: You'd lie to save your friend.
answer: No. There's no friends for me.

question: Me the same. Pity us both. Hold your fire! In there! Hey in there! I want to talk to Amsterdam!
answer: Go on, then, talk.

question: You and me.
answer: Come ahead then. And bring my friend's body.

question: Your friend made different friends lately.
answer: Tammany's put us all in the same place. You want to get out alive?

question: It don't matter to me. I got enemies outside, enemies in here. The militia can move on me anytime. You could drop me before I get to the door.
answer: I don't want to lose you so easy. You'll never get past the militia unless you come with the Dead Rabbits.

question: You'd lay aside what's between us?
answer: I'm not forgetting where I put it.

question: If you do, I'll remind you.
answer: What's your call, Bill?
